an3.124:1.1: “Mendicants, I’m not even comfortable thinking about a place where mendicants argue—quarreling and fighting, continually wounding each other with barbed words—let alone going there.
an3.124:1.2: I come to a conclusion about them:
an3.124:1.3: ‘Clearly those venerables have given up three things and cultivated three things.’
an3.124:1.4: What three things have they given up?
an3.124:1.5: Thoughts of renunciation, good will, and harmlessness.
an3.124:1.7: What three things have they cultivated?
an3.124:1.11: I come to a conclusion about them:
an3.124:1.12: ‘Clearly those venerables have given up three things and cultivated three things.’
an3.124:2.1: I feel comfortable going to a place where the mendicants live in harmony—appreciating each other, without quarreling, blending like milk and water, and regarding each other with kindly eyes—let alone thinking about it.
an3.124:2.2: I come to a conclusion about them:
an3.124:2.3: ‘Clearly those venerables have given up three things and cultivated three things.’
an3.124:2.4: What three things have they given up?
an3.124:2.7: What three things have they cultivated?
an3.124:2.8: Thoughts of renunciation, good will, and harmlessness. …
an3.124:2.11: I come to a conclusion about them:
an3.124:2.12: ‘Clearly those venerables have given up three things and cultivated three things.’”
